summary: Federal employee whistleblowers—people who report legal or ethical violations or mismanagement—help fight fraud, waste, and abuse. Laws seek to protect them from reprisal, but probationary employees, usually those with 1 to 2 years on the job, have fewer protections. More than 14,000 federal workers filed whistleblower cases from FY 2014–2018. Each year, about 120 to 270 of them were probationary. Our estimates suggest that probationary...
title: Whistleblowers: Office of Special Counsel Should Require Information on the Probationary Status of Whistleblowers
